Award.AwardTitle: Advances in Quantum and Low-Dimensional Topology; March 2016; University of Iowa
Award.AbstractNarration:
The conference "Advances in Quantum and Low-Dimensional Topology" will be held at the University of Iowa in March 11-13, 2016. This award provides travel support for conference participants with a focus on funding junior investigators, students, mathematicians from underrepresented groups, and other active researchers without their own sources of funding. The goals of the conference are to (1) provide an environment fostering formation of new collaborative communities between mathematicians at all levels and in varying disciplines that touch on quantum and low-dimensional topology; (2) to energize and advance transformative research in the areas of quantum and low-dimensional topology; and (3) involve new Ph.D. recipients, graduate students, and mathematicians from underrepresented groups in this active research area. It will also allow leading researchers to disseminate their ideas to a larger audience.

This conference will focus on quantum invariants for knots and three-manifolds and topics connected to these. These invariants possess a rich structure and, in addition to quantum groups, relate to statistical mechanics, quantum field theory, and affine Lie algebras. Presenters have been working on the A-polynomial, skein module quantizations of character varieties, skein algebras, categorified invariants, and other algebraic and combinatorial themes motivated by knot theory. In recent years there has been an explosion of interest in these topics as well as their applications and potential impact on other areas of scientific investigations. There are many new connections to explore in the future. The conference will attract many researchers working in quantum and low-dimensional topology, and their ramifications, and will be a venue for diversity and breadth of participation not only by individuals but also by institutions. The program will provide ample opportunity for graduate students, postdocs, and other young scientists to present their work.

The conference website will be located at https://sites.google.com/site/advquantlowstop2016/.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The conference "Advances in Quantum and Low-Dimensional Topology" was held at the University of Iowa in March 11-13, 2016.

The goal of the conference was to bring together researchers and students interested in quantum and low-dimensional topology in order to promote advancement in the field, stimulate new collaborations, and forge new directions for research. Significant emphasis was placed on attracting participation from Ph.D. students, recent Ph.D. recipients, women, and minorities.

The conference promoted high quality scientific discourse and provided opportunities for future collaborations and investigations while strengthening the research community in the active area of quantum and low-dimensional topology. The conference provided graduate students, recent Ph.D. recipients, and mathematicians with active research programs but limited support an excellent opportunity to discuss their work with others, including well-known experts, learn about the latest methods in the field, and seek new research problems to explore.

The conference attracted 123 participants working in fields related to quantum and low-dimensional topology. The population of participants was diverse in terms of demographics as well as type of institution and level of career. 10% of the participants came from abroad and 24% of the total participants were women. Among of all participants, 31% were graduate students and 27% were young mathematicians (less than 10 years since receiving their Ph.D.).

There were 6 plenary talks given by established researchers in their field (two of which were women). There were also 66 twenty-minute talks organized in three parallel sessions (21% and, respectively, 33% of these talks were given by women and graduate students).
